text.__SUMMARY__:
The hourglass dolphin (Lagenorhynchus cruciger) is a small dolphin in the family Delphinidae that inhabits Antarctic and subantarctic waters [10].
The dolphin has rarely been seen. It was identified as a new species by Jean René Constant Quoy and Joseph Paul Gaimard in 1824 from a drawing made in the South Pacific in 1820 [3]. It is the only cetacean to have been widely accepted as a species solely on witness accounts.
text.Description:
The hourglass dolphin is colored black on top and white on the belly, with white patches on the sides [1].  and sometimes variations of dark grey. For this reason, it was colloquially known by whalers as a "sea cow" (although it does not belong to the taxonomic order Sirenia.)[1]. Each flank has a white patch at the front, above the beak, eye and flipper, and a second patch at the rear [1]. These two patches are connected by a thin white strip, creating, loosely speaking, an hourglass shape; hence the common name of the dolphin [1]. The scientific name cruciger is Latin for "cross-carrier". This refers to the area of black coloration, which, viewed from above, vaguely resembles a Maltese cross or cross pattée. There have been no verified sightings of calves and their coloration remains unknown.
In its usual range the dolphin is easily identifiable. Only The southern right whale dolphin is the only cetacean of comparable size and that lives as far south [4]. The right whale dolphin does not have a dorsal fin, so the two species are easily distinguished. The fin considerably varies across individuals. It is generally tall and curved, and the curve may be particularly pronounced in older animals.
An adult male is about 1.8 meters (5.9 ft) in length and weighs over 90 kilograms (about 200 lbs) [3][5]. and weighs 90–120 kilograms (200–260 lb) Juvenile females range from 1.6-1.8 meters (5.2-5.9 ft) in length and weigh from 70-90 kilograms (154-200 lbs) [3]. Males are thought to be slightly smaller and lighter than females, although the small number of specimens does not permit a firm conclusion.
Like all species of dolphin, they use echolocation to find food [9].
text.Geographic Range and Distribution: The range is circumpolar from close to the Antarctic ice pack to about 45°S [10]. The most northerly northernmost confirmed sightings were 36°S in the South Atlantic Ocean and 33°S near Valparaíso, Chile, in the Pacific [12]. Sightings have been made most commonly from the south of New Zealand, around the South Shetland Islands [11] and off Tierra del Fuego, Argentina [12]. The species is unlikely to be particularly densely populated close to these lands.
text.Behavior:
Hourglass dolphins tend to move in groups of up to 10-15 [4], though groups of up to 100 have been observed.
They share feeding grounds with other cetaceans such as pilot whales, minke whales and southern right whale dolphins [4]. They are regularly seen with fin whales [4]. Hourglass dolphins frequently bow-ride waves from ships and baleen whales bow-wave riders [4].
Examinations of the stomach contents of the few specimens indicate they eat mantis shrimp, polychaete worms, and various (unrecorded) species of squid and small fish [7].
text.Taxonomy:
The species was first named Delphinus cruciger by Quoy and Gaimard (1824) after their sighting in January 1820 [3]. Lesson and Garnot (1827) named another dolphin with 2 white patches on the sides Delphinus bivittatus [3]. Throughout the 19th and early 20th centuries, scientists have given the hourglass dolphin various synonyms including Phocoena crucigera (Philippi, 1893), Electra crucigera (Gray, 1871), and Lagenorhynchus clanculus (Gray, 1846; 1849; 1850; 1866) [3]. 
Though it is traditionally placed in the genus Lagenorhynchus, molecular analyses suggest the species be returned to the genus Sagmatias [6].  More recent molecular analyses indicate that the hourglass dolphin is actually more closely related to dolphins of the genus Cephalorhynchus [8].
text.Population Status: Sighting surveys were conducted from 1976-77 to 1987-88 [2]. Abundance was estimated to be 144,300 individuals based on line transect sightings in January 1977 and January 1988 in northern Antarctic waters [2]. This is the only abundance estimate of hourglass dolphins to date [2].
text.Threats: There are no known major threats to hourglass dolphins as of 2018, and as such the species is listed as Least Concern on the IUCN Red List [14].
text.Conservation Status: The hourglass dolphin is covered by the Memorandum of Understanding for the Conservation of Cetaceans and Their Habitats in the Pacific Islands Region (Pacific Cetaceans MOU)[13]. They are also listed in Appendix II of  the 2003 Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) [14]. Although they have not been studied extensively, they are of least concern to conservationists.
